qas.question: From where did Eisenhower get the idea of a White House Chief of Staff?
Who was the last president not to appoint a Chief of Staff?
Along with Ford, what president initially didn't appoint a Chief of Staff but later did?
What 19th century informal political office did the modern role of White House Chief of Staff correspond to?

context: Since the 19th century, many if not all presidents were assisted by a central figure or "gatekeeper", sometimes described as the <a3_0>President's Private Secretary<a3_0/>, sometimes with no official title at all. Eisenhower formalized this role, introducing the office of White House Chief of Staff – an idea he borrowed from the <a0_0>United States Army<a0_0/>. Every president after <a1_0>Lyndon Johnson<a1_0/> has also appointed staff to this position. Initially, Gerald Ford and <a2_0>Jimmy Carter<a2_0/> tried to operate without a chief of staff, but each eventually appointed one.
